title: Untitled
text:
Archaeologists have uncovered ancient garden remains beneath the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem, supporting the Gospel of John’s account of Jesus’ burial near a garden. Pollen and soil samples revealed olive trees and grapevines from around 2,000 years ago.

The excavation began in 2022 as part of a rare renovation, requiring approval from the church’s three custodians and Israel’s Antiquities Authority. Researchers also found pottery, oil lamps, and burial sites spanning from the Iron Age to early Christianity.

A marble base matching early church descriptions and stone walls filled with soil were discovered, suggesting a quarry turned garden before becoming a burial site. A digital reconstruction is underway, with final excavations set to resume after Easter.

The lead archaeologist said: “The Gospel mentions a green area between the Calvary and the tomb, and we identified these cultivated fields.”
